text: happy Boxing Day I'm Hank green welcome
to a special year-end double wide
edition of scishow breaking news each
year brings us a wealth of new knowledge
all kinds of wondrous revelations of
things we never knew before and I could
never condense all that into just a few
minutes could I I'd have to talk really
fast since we here at scishow we're all
about more learning more understanding
more explaining more I wanted to end our
inaugural season together by giving you
nothing but superlatives the biggest
oldest first last smallest and hottest
developments in science from 2012 let's
start out by winding the clock back to
last January on January 12th a team of
American biologists announced that they
discovered the world's smallest
vertebrate a frog just 7.7 millimeters
long in the forests of Papua New Guinea
the species given the name Pettifer an M
I insist was hard to detect because you
may have noticed its pretty tiny and it
lives on the forest floor amongst all
the leave assigned to say that its
discovery suggests that many more
species of such tiny amphibians are just
waiting to be found
now skipping ahead to May one
anthropologist announced the discovery
of the world's oldest musical
instruments excavators found four flutes
carved from vulture bones in mammoth
ivory and caves in southwestern German
the same cave system are one of the
famous zaftig fertility figures known as
Venus figurines had been found
radiocarbon dating put the flutes age at
42,000 years old 7,000 years older than
were originally thought and more than 40
thousand years before jethro tull
released thick as a brick then on May
25th an international group of
astronomers finally announced the
location of the world's largest radio
telescope after years of debate the
decision was made to place thousands of
antennae throughout nine countries in
southern Africa as well as Australia and
New Zealand to create a combined signal
collecting area of one square kilometre
the project called the Square Kilometre
Array will be 50 to 100 times more
sensitive than any existing radio
telescope and is expected to be online
by 2025 and on that exact same day the
spacex dragon spacecraft became the
first commercial vehicle to dock with
the International
Space Station assuring in a new era of
regular private-sector spaceflight the
Dragon capsule brought non-essential
supplies to the ISS and splashed down
safely in the Pacific Ocean on May 31st
dragon has since completed another
successful resupply mission in October
and is scheduled to conduct two more in
2013 on June 26 physicists at Brookhaven
National Laboratory and up to New York
said that they had smashed together ions
of gold to produce the highest man-made
temperature ever recorded four trillion
degrees Celsius that's about a quarter
million times hotter than the core of
the Sun you guys thought they just
announced it in June the physicists
actually reached this record melting
temperature back in 2010 while producing
also for the first time quark-gluon
plasma a kind of haze of fundamental
particles similar to what appeared in
the first instance after the Big Bang so
it's a twofer not to be outdone on July
4th physicists at CERN in Switzerland
said that they were quote statistically
confident that they'd found the last
undiscovered particle predicted by the
standard model of physics the Higgs
boson the boson is thought to be an
indicator of the Higgs field a
theoretical fog of particles that
essentially gives mass to particles that
interact with it
physicists used CERN's 27-kilometer
particle collider to generate enough
energy for such bosons to briefly appear
and after analyzing 800 trillion
collisions over the past two years CERN
detected a boson with a mass around 125
billion electron volts that they think
is the Higgs the experts said they
should have their final official
findings about this discovery ready in
the spring on August 6 the Mars Science
Laboratory safely landed on Mars making
it the largest and therefore awesomest
probe to ever reach the planet's surface
the suite of 11 instruments the MSL is
three metres long weighs 900 kilograms
and arrived by way of the most precise
landing ever executed flying 560 6.5
million kilometres to land within a
target only 20 kilometers across the
whole month of September meanwhile was
one for the record books though not in a
good way as of September 19th Arctic sea
ice reached its lowest coverage-area
ever recorded just 3.4 million square
kilometers half the average minimum
level
from 1979 to 2000 perhaps not
surprisingly September 2012 was tied
with 2005 for the hottest September ever
with an average global temperature of 15
degrees Celsius 0.67 degrees Celsius
above the 20th century average on
November 22nd Italian scientists
released the first direct images ever
taken of DNA using the new sample
preparation method the researchers were
able to isolate a double strand of DNA
and capture images of it with a scanning
electron microscope the evidence
provided the first photographic proof of
DNA's double helix structure that we
were pretty sure about it before we took
the picture to be completely honest and
finally paleontologists announced on
December 4th the discovery of the oldest
known dinosaur American and British
scientists found the fossil bones of the
dog sized nyasa Soros pairing Tony in
Tanzania and dated them back 243 million
years about 10 million years before the
earliest known specimen discovery not
only pushes back the first known
appearance of dinos the researchers say
but it also firmly places the birthplace
of dinosaurs and what are now the
southern continents there you have it a
year's worth of discoveries at about
five minutes and only because like a
talk so fast thank you to everyone who's

it's been great to have your support and
we hope that you stick with us in our
